MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 2.30 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Authority Membership.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach whether any member of the Government is a member of a local authority; and, if so, whether he approves of their continued membership.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: In accordance with the practice normally followed by Governments in recent years, the following Ministers have resigned from membership of local authorities: Minister for the Public Service, Mr. John Boland; Minister for Transport and Minister for Posts and Telegraphs, Mr. Jim Mitchell; Minister for Health and Minister for Social Welfare, Mr. Barry Desmond and Minister for Agriculture, Mr. Austin Deasy.

The following Ministers have indicated that they will be resigning: Tánaiste and Minister for the Environment, Mr. Dick Spring; Minister for Labour, Mr. Liam Kavanagh; Minister for Justice. Mr. Michael Noonan.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Potato Imports.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the value of imports of potatoes in 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett, Dún Laoghaire) Nuala Fennell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett,
Speaker.P: Dún Laoghaire): The value of potatoes imported in 1982 was as follows:

row.entry: Flour, meal and flakes of potato

MainHeading.P: That compares with £14.7 million in 1981.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: What was the first figure the Minister gave?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): £13.5 million.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: What was that for?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): Fresh or chilled potatoes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: Would the Minister of State regard this as a matter of concern since we are primarily an agricultural country? In the past we were big exporters of potatoes in all forms. It would seem there has been a drastic reduction in exports and a big improvement in imports.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: This is a statistical question and the Minister of State is not responsible for policy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: Perhaps the Minister of State would ask the Minister for Agriculture if he proposes to introduce any incentive to farmers to redress this scandalous situation.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy should put down a question about that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: The Minister of State might have the information to hand.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): It is a shame that we are importing such large quantities of potatoes.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Lemass Mrs. Lemass
Speaker.P: Is it compulsory to indicate on bags of potatoes that they are imported? When a housewife goes into a supermarket she does not know what is imported and what is home grown.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Minister of State is responsible only for the records of imports and exports and not for the matters raised by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hilliard Mr. Hilliard
Speaker.P: Will the Minister of State convey to the Minister for Agriculture the fact that farmers today are taking £30 and £35 a ton for potatoes while it costs £75 a ton to break even?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy Hilliard should put down a question on that. The Chair might indicate at this juncture that statistical questions are put down for the purpose of obtaining the information asked for.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): I should like to be helpful.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Minister of State is not being helpful.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): I should like to give some statistics to the House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Only if they are statistics.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): In 1982 virtually all imports of fresh and chilled potatoes and over 96 per cent of processed potatoes came from other EEC member states. The Netherlands and Northern Ireland were the principal suppliers.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Donegal Unemployed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the number of persons registered as unemployed in each employment exchange in County Donegal at the latest date for which figures are available; and on the corresponding date in 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): I propose to circulate a statement giving the information sought by the Deputy.
Following is the statement:

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: What is the percentage of the total work force presently unemployed in Donegal? How does this figure compare with the rest of the country?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): I do not have the percentage. That was not part of the question. The question asked about numbers. On 29 January 1982 the figure was 9,787 and on 28 January 1983 it was 11,147.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the quantity and value of cement imports in 1980 and 1981.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): Imports of cement, excluding clinker, amounted to 97,300 tonnes, value £4.4 million in 1980 and 52,600 tonnes, value £3.1 million in 1981.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: The Minister looked as if he would proceed further. Perhaps he was going to give the reason why there was a decrease in the 1981 figure.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: He probably thought of the Chair's ruling and desisted.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: Will he finish the sentence? He is most helpful.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): I have already given the information.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: I take it that there will be a substantial increase in the amount of imports in 1983 to accommodate the 30,000 new house starts which the Minister for the Environment has promised.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Authority Houses.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.NameTxt: Mr. Molloy, Mr. S. Walsh and Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment (a) the number of local authority houses sold to tenants in each of the past five years; (b) if he has satisfied himself with the present method of assessing the sale price of local authority houses; and (c) if he will ensure that a greater number of new tenants are afforded the opportunity of purchasing their dwellings.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Spring) Dick Spring
Speaker.P: According to information supplied by the authorities, the number of local authority houses sold to tenants thereof in the years in question was as follows: 1978, 2,934 houses; 1979, 4,393 houses; 1980, 4,949 houses; 1981, 4,087 houses.
Details of the number of dwellings sold in 1982 are not yet available.

It has been the general policy that all tenants of local authority dwellings, other than dwellings specifically provided for elderly persons, should be afforded the opportunity of purchasing their dwellings. The 1981-82 scheme expired on 31 January 1983 and I expect that discussions on a new scheme to take effect from 1 February 1983 will take place shortly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: Will the Minister give an undertaking to the House that there will not be a reduction in the amount of local authority dwellings to be completed in the coming year?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: That is a different question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: I understand the Minister is due to meet the County Managers' Association on Thursday next and I imagine that that item will be discussed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I will be dealing with that matter specifically on Question No. 9.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: If the details for 1982 are not available, has he any estimate for that year?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: No, I do not have an estimate available at this stage but as soon as information becomes available I will put it before the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Clare) Mr. Barrett (Clare)
Speaker.P: (Clare): Could I ask the Minister when it is expected that the purchase scheme for 1983 will be available to local authorities?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I hope to have it available within a matter of weeks.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Sale of Flats.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Doyle Mr. J. Doyle
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when he intends to sanction Dublin Corporation's scheme for the sale of flats to tenants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: The corporation's proposals are at present being examined in my Department. The Department's views on the proposals will be conveyed to the corporation as soon as this examination is completed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Doyle Mr. J. Doyle
Speaker.P: In view of the interest shown by the tenants in the proposed scheme and the beneficial effects it will have, could the Minister expedite his decision in this matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I assure the Deputy that a decision will be forthcoming in a matter of weeks.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Authority House Sales.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will state whether in cases where a tenant purchaser of a local authority house undertakes to carry out agreed pre-sale repairs to the house the cost can be deducted from the purchase price.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: The existing legislation which governs the sale of local authority houses does not permit the cost of agreed pre-sale repairs undertaken by a tenant to be deducted from the purchase price of the house. A tenant may, however, enter into an agreement with a housing authority that he will, within a specified time after the making of a transfer order, carry out or arrange to have carried out the works necessary to put the house into good structural repair. In such cases the authority will recoup to the tenant the agreed cost when the work has been completed to the satisfaction of the authority.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that local authorities are finding it very difficult to enact the present legislation? Would he agree that there should be some amendment whereby the local authorities could enter into an arrangement with tenants who are prepared to purchase houses and so get over this difficulty which is causing grave concern to local authorities in relation to carrying out repairs?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I accept that difficulties have been encountered, from my own experience in a local authority, under section 13 of the Housing (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1979. We all wish to facilitate tenants to have repairs carried out and it is a matter I shall look into.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Lemass Mrs. Lemass
Speaker.P: Does the Minister agree that what he has stated does not always happen? Because a tenant has signed an agreement to purchase his house, has 21 days and pays £5 to the Department of the Environment, it does not always follow that his repairs, as promised, are carried out? In those circumstances, has that tenant any legal status to ensure that the work is carried out or can he insist that the work be carried out?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That seems to be a different question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I want to assure the Deputy that if the tenant purchaser is not satisfied with the structural condition of the house when it is transferred to him, he may, within the 21 days mentioned by Deputy Lemass, apply to the Minister for the Environment to determine any doubts in this regard. I can assure the Deputy there will be no delay on my part in determining any questions which may arise.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Tenant Purchase Agreement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when work will be carried out for a person (details supplied) in County Wexford following his appeal under section 106 of the Housing Act, 1966 relating to his tenant purchase agreement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: The carrying out of the works in question is a matter for Wexford County Council. I understand from the council that they hope to carry out the works within the next few weeks.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Authority House Completions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.NameTxt: Mr. Molloy, Mr. S. Walsh and Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the number of local authority houses completed in each of the past three years; and if he will give an estimate of the number of completions provided for in 1983.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: The information requested is as follows: 1980—5, 984; 1981—5,681; 1982—5,686. It is estimated that 5,800 houses will be completed in 1983.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: The Minister will recall that this time last year the Minister for the Environment discovered that the allocations provided to the local authorities were inadequate. Later on in the year the Minister provided local authorities with an extra contribution——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: A question, please, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: Is it the Minister's intention to ensure that the local authorities will receive an adequate amount of money to build sufficient houses? I would also like to ask if the sums are found to be inadequate now, will they be supplemented later on in the year?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: The provision of £208 million for 1983 for the provision of local authority houses is an increase from the £187.5 million provided last year and I am optimistic that that sum will be adequate to complete the programme as outlined.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: If the Minister has the information available perhaps he would give me the breakdown of the local authority houses proposed for Mayo, Galway and Donegal?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: Has the Minister got the information on his file?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: No, I have not got it on the file.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kerry Housing Allocation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the amount of money being allocated to Kerry County Council this year for housing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: An application by Kerry County Council for a capital allocation to finance their housing programme is being considered in conjunction with similar claims submitted by other housing authorities. Notification of the 1983 allocations will be issued to housing authorities shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Damage to Property Legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will introduce legislation so that legal and other costs can be met from central funds in relation to the increasing costs to local authorities in Border regions of contesting claims for malicious injuries and damage to property as a result of Northern Ireland troubles.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: While I am aware of the way in which such legal and other costs can affect the finances of local authorities and am keeping the position under review, the Deputy will appreciate that the introduction of any legislation relating to the malicious injuries code is not a matter for me.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Local Authorities Revenue.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: and Mr. Fitzsimons asked the Minister for the Environment when an announcement will be made giving details of the proposed new local charges and increases in existing charges by which local authorities are to raise about £65 million in extra revenue.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I propose to issue a communication to local authorities as soon as possible on this matter in the context of the preparation of their estimates for 1983.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: From the £65 million it is proposed to get by way of extra charges for services this year from local authorities, it is estimated that about £2 million will have to be collected from ratepayers in County Mayo. This would be in excess of the total amount received by rates on commercial properties and it would involve enormous charges. Is the Minister aware of the exact level of charges that the sums he speaks about would entail? Does he realise people will not be in a position to meet this kind of demand and what is he going to do to provide extra money for local authorities to prevent them from going bankrupt?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: The imposition of charges by me will be far less than those which would have been necessary if we had allowed the £97 million shortfall which I found in the Estimates for my Department. The new estimate of £65 million is far less than that and the charges will, obviously, be reduced accordingly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: It is about time that the Minister and the Government got away from the gambit of blaming everything that might have to be done in 1983 on what was proposed for 1982. They are the Government now. It is time they lived up to their obligations and if they have a shortage of money it is up to them to provide for it and not be blaming previous Governments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I am sure the Deputy will agree that the extra £31.5 million from the Department as opposed to the shortfall in the original estimates is no mean sum and will be of benefit to the local authorities in carrying out their obligations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: Does the Minister realise that he has thrown an incendiary device into the local authorities which will blow up in his face at any moment? What does he propose doing about it and why is the Minister of State, Deputy Quinn, getting so hot and bothered?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: The Minister stated earlier on that he would be meeting the County Managers' Association on Thursday next. Will the information in relation to the extra charges which the Minister will be advising them to impose in the various counties be available for county council meetings next Monday?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: No, that information will be given to the House before it is made available to anyone else. It will not be made available to county managers on Thursday.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: While I can appreciate that the Minister is anxious to leave the House to evade answering questions on this subject——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: I never feel any necessity to evade a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: When does the Minister intend to bring before the House the measure to implement this £65 million charge on ratepayers? Surely they are entitled to at least know that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Spring Mr. Spring
Speaker.P: If the Deputy is finished with his frivolous questions I can go off and attend to the business of my Department and we will have it at an early date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Flynn Mr. Flynn
Speaker.P: It is the business of the Minister's Department and it is here he should be answering questions about the business of his Department.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Water and Sewerage Schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the expected date of the completion of the sewerage scheme at Cavan; and its capacity vis-á-vis current industrial domestic demand in the area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Quinn) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Quinn)
Speaker.P: I assume the Deputy is referring to the sewerage scheme catering for industrial development at Killygarry, Cavan, which is due for completion in early 1984. The design capacity of the proposed sewage treatment works is 180,000 gallons per day. It would be a matter for Cavan County Council to determine how much, if any, of this capacity is additional to present requirements, on completion of the treatment works.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilsón Mr. Wilsón
Speaker.P: Will the Minister of State see to it that there will be no restrictions on the use of the scheme in view of the serious unemployment in the construction industry in the area and also the growing unemployment of young people in the area who require manufacturing industry to be established in the complex on that road?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I will take note of what the Deputy has said.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the sewerage schemes for Counties Cavan and Monaghan for which money is being made available in 1983.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The capital returns for 87 sanitary authorities are being analysed in my Department. On the basis of these returns, I hope to be in a position to determine the allocations for the current year shortly. I am not, at present, in a position to anticipate the amount of allocations to be made to individual sanitary authorities. I can, however, say that whatever allocation is made will include adequate capital moneys to fund the sewerage schemes which are at present in progress in Counties Cavan and Monaghan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Does that mean that the Minister of State does not envisage any new starts in the sewerage scheme?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: No, it does not. It means exactly what I said. I am not in a position to give the detailed breakdown for each of the 87 sanitary authorities but there is sufficient provision to give an assurance that the existing schemes will be maintained.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: The Minister's attitude prompted the question. He is positive about the existing one. I want to know if he has any doubts about other projected ones.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is well aware, every local authority in every year have more schemes up on the desk of the Department than there is money available for them. Therefore, it is a question of how much is made available, then it is a matter for each local authority to decide which schemes they want to promote in that year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the present position of the proposed East Inishowen water scheme, County Donegal.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Contract documents for this scheme have been submitted to my Department by Donegal County Council and are under consideration at present. In view, however, of the large number of fully approved schemes in progress or getting to construction for which adequate finance must be provided, I cannot say at this stage when I will be in a position to approve the contract documents for the East Inishowen scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: Could the Minister of State tell me when the contract documents were sent to the Department and also whether an EEC FEOGA grant was approved and, if so, for what amount and in what year? Also, has the scheme been put forward for a European Investment Bank loan?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I think that is three questions. First of all, the contract documents were submitted as far back as 23 July 1976. Secondly, the scheme qualified for £53,000 grant from the FEOGA fund. What was the Deputy's third question?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: Has any scheme been put forward for a loan from the European Investment Bank?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I do not have that information available in my brief.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: Is the amount of grant that has been approved still available or has the time run out for the pick-up of that grant?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I do not know the answer to that question. I will get the details for the Deputy and write to him directly on it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: In view of the long delay in approving or sanctioning this scheme is the Minister aware that in that area there is a grave shortage in relation to water and also that many applications are with Donegal County Council for planning approval which cannot be granted due to no water being available? This in turn is creating a problem in relation to employment in an area which has a very high unemployment record as was indicated by another Minister in answer to a previous question. Would the Minister of State consider at this stage that after seven years it is time that at least this scheme should be brought to the top of the pile as far as Donegal County Council are concerned?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I hesitate to interfere in the internal affairs of Donegal County Council, but I draw the Deputy's attention to the fact that Donegal County Council have listed this scheme as only ninth in their order of priority. The question of priority spending within each local authority is first and foremost the responsibility of the local authority. If the Deputy is concerned, as obviously he is, then it would appear that the most effective way he can effect that is to get it reverted in the order of priorities within Donegal County Council.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Cavan Road.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the date he expects work to resume on the Cavan-Longford road at Mullahoran, County Cavan.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I will bear in mind the financial requirements of the work when the road grant allocations for 1983 are being determined. The timing of a resumption of work at this location will then be a matter primarily for Cavan County Council as road authority.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Am I to take it from the words used by the Minister of State that he is pretty sure that moneys will be available for the resumption of work on that road?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I am quite confident that those moneys will be made available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will make an increased allowance for roads to those counties which now have no rail service; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I have noted the needs of the roads in the counties to which the Deputy refers in my consideration of the road grant allocations for 1983. It is, however, estimated that, as railways carry a relatively small volume of traffic compared to roads, the presence or absence of railways is not regarded as a major factor in the determination of the amounts of road grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Is the Minister of State aware that when a case was being made for the suspension of a railway service to certain areas assurances were given in the past that there would be an extra allotment for areas not covered by a rail service? Would he like to say if he agrees with that approach and to put a percentage?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Deputy will be interested to learn from the brief that I have here that in relation to the railway closures in Cavan, Monaghan and Donegal special grants were allocated to those counties as follows: Cavan £225,000, Monaghan £225,000, Donegal £375,000.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: When?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I have not got that information here. I will find out for the Deputy and will communicate with him. The principle of his argument has been conceded in this and moneys were delivered.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: Could I remind the Minister that the figures he has read out were granted to these counties back in the fifties? Further, I suggest that, while they may have met the immediate problems at the time, the continuing deterioration of our roads because of the lack of any mode of transport other than road transport has not been covered since then. Deputy Wilson's question would tend to alleviate that situation if special consideration were once again given to the problem of these counties.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: I have one final supplementary. If the Minister of State did a survey and found out what percentage the original allocation was of the total amount and applied that percentage now it would be a step forward.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: If the Deputy would like to put down a question to that effect I will make the information available to him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the reason for the delay in paying a £600 grant which is due to a person (details supplied) in County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Grants of £600 and £150 respectively were paid in this case in respect of house improvement works and the provision of sewerage facilities in May 1981.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment when a £500 mortgage subsidy which has been due since November 1982 will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Galway.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: This payment will be made shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Planning Applications and Appeals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: and Mr. Fitzsimons asked the Minister for the Environment if he will state in respect of the charges for planning applications and appeals: (a) the estimated revenue; (b) whether local authorities will retain the revenue; and if he will make a statement on these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: It is estimated that planning application fees will yield about £5.5 million in 1983 and that appeal fees will yield about £100,000. All moneys raised by planning application fees will accrue to the planning authority concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: Would the Minister of State say from when these charges will be effective or come into operation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: They will come in from 7 March for planning applications and a month later for appeals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware, as I have no doubt he is as far as Dublin by-laws of both city and county are concerned, that some planning applications would apply only to by-laws? In that case will charges be related to by-law applications?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I am not sure that I understand the Deputy's question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: For a certain square footage only by-law approval is required.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: No, the fees related only to planning permission. Applications for house extensions, for by-law approval, will not be covered by planning fees regulations if they are under the exempted floor areas.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: In relation to extensive planning applications for housing or industrial developments where it may be necessary after consultation with the architects or developers to withdraw the original application and re-submit, will there be an additional charge?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: There is a charge for each separate planning application lodged with a planning authority but where an application is made following an earlier one substantial discounts are provided for in the details of the scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: Is £30 to be charged for an application for one house?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: That is correct.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: I would have thought that commercial and industrial developments would have been a much fairer target than young married couples endeavouring to build a house. Is the charge of £30 not somewhat excessive?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Presumably there will be an opportunity for debate on these regulations and, if not, I am sure one can be created. It would not be appropriate to have an extensive debate on the regulations now.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Fitzsimons Mr. Fitzsimons
Speaker.P: While there is nothing wrong with the local authority trying to raise money through the planning applications, my view is that it would be far better to raise it through applications for housing, commercial and industrial developments rather than single house applications.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The point the Chair is making is that it would be more appropriate for a debate.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not consider that the charges could be regarded as too expensive in regard to one house applications? Would the Minister not consider that the charge should be made only when an application is successful or when an appeal is successful? A person who fails to get planning permission should not have to pay for that privilege.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I appreciate the sentiments expressed by Deputy Blaney. However, nationwide the average cost of a new house is £35,000 and in our view a charge of £30 for each house application is not excessive. It does not in any way cover the cost of administration. An extension will not be built for less than £3,000 or £4,000 and a charge of £15 is not excessive. Even allowing for people building their own houses and a certain degree of co-operative construction in rural areas, a new house will still cost between £15,000 and £20,000. We spent a long time considering this matter and do not feel that a charge of £30 is excessive but I would say——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Surely we are debating these regulations without seeing them. Question No. 21.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: The Minister of State has said that the money which will be raised will be left with the local authorities. Will he state whether this will be additional money for them or will it be deducted from the moneys normally advanced to local authorities by the Department of the Environment?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: It will be additional money.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Access for Disabled.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Ormonde Dr. Ormonde
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if, in view of the fact that the Local Government (Planning and Development) Act, 1963, has inadequate provisions in respect of access for the disabled, he will amend the Act so that if local authorities refused planning permission on the grounds of inadequate access for the disabled and if the applicant appeals to the planning authority, the local authorities would not be overruled and liable for costs; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The provision of access for the disabled is not basically a planning matter and it would be inappropriate to approach the matter on the lines suggested by the Deputy. It would be more appropriate to building regulations which are being prepared in my Department. These regulations will include standards to cater for the special needs of the disabled in regard to access to buildings. When the regulations are made, these standards will be obligatory in relation to all appropriate buildings.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: Did the Minister say when the regulations would be ready?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: No. The technical content of the regulations has been completed but we need to bring in new legislation for their administration. I hope this will be done before June.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Toxic Waste.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: and Mr. De Rossa asked the Minister for the Environment if it is intended to proceed with the development of a storage depot for toxic waste at Baldonnel, County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: and Mr. De Rossa asked the Minister for the Environment the plans he has for the disposal of the toxic waste which it is intended to store at Baldonnel, County Dublin, and at other sites.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 22 and 23 together.

As I indicated in reply to a question on this subject on 2 February 1983, the arrangements generally relating to the development of the proposed central facility for certain wastes have been under review. I expect to be in a position to make a statement in the matter shortly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: I am sure the Minister is aware of the great public concern in regard to toxic wastes, which are increasing as a result of the development of chemical industries. He states that he has the matter under review and expects to be able to make a decision shortly. In view of the fact that this matter has been under review by two previous Governments and that no decision has been made, does he regard the matter as one of grave urgency?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I share Deputy Mac Giolla's assessment of the public concern in relation to this matter but he will realise that we have had no previous experience of the matter in this country. We are endeavouring to get the right solution from the start. We will not hesitate in coming to a conclusion but neither will we move too fast.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: I would agree with the Minister that we must get the right solution. I take it the Minister would not have a collection centre for toxic waste until he had a disposal procedure for it. It is intended to have a collection centre at Baldonnel but I presume that would not be established unless there were some area for the disposal of toxic waste.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Deputy has put his finger on part of the overall problem. Unless we have a continuous process in dealing with this matter from start to finish, we will not have a proper solution. We are looking at the entire question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: The Rathcoole Community Council are very concerned about this matter and are anxious to get as much information as possible. Will the Minister agree to meet a deputation from the local community organisation to discuss the matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I will consider the request.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: and Mr. Mac Giolla asked the Minister for the Environment if he will list the sites which have been approved by his Department for the storage or disposal of toxic and other hazardous industrial wastes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: and Mr. Mac Giolla asked the Minister for the Environment the system his Department operates to monitor the disposal of toxic and other hazardous industrial wastes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 24 and 25 together.

The statutory powers governing the storage, movement and disposal of toxic and dangerous waste are vested in local authorities under the European Communities (Toxic and Dangerous Waste) Regulations, 1982, which came into operation on 1 January 1983. The regulations provide for a number of controls including a permit system and a consignment note system which enable local authorities to monitor the movement of the relevant wastes from source to ultimate point of disposal.

MainHeading.P: The selection of sites for their own waste disposal operations and the approval of private disposal sites are matters for the local authority. My approval is not necessary to the sites selected by local authorities and there is no list of such sites in my Department. The role of the Department is mainly in the area of issuing advice to local authorities, and guidelines were recently issued to them on the factors to be taken into account in site selection.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: Will the Minister renew the commitment given by the last Minister for the Environment that the Dunsink dump in the Finglas area will not be used for toxic waste? As there are no official dumps at present will the Minister indicate what is being done with the toxic waste?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I am not in the position to give an answer to the Deputy to the first part of his question in regard to Dunsink. If the Deputy tables a specific question about that matter I will get the information for him. It is not that I am not answering the Deputy but I am not in a position to give him the information. In reply to the second part of the Deputy's supplementary I should like to state that there is no clear policy in regard to the disposal of toxic waste throughout the country. It is primarily a matter for local authorities to respond to EEC regulations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: Will the Minister agree that the proper fulfilment by the local authorities of the tasks designated by him under the legislation to monitor the control and disposal of the toxic waste will require expert staff in the employment of local authorities? Will the Minister look favourably on applications that may be submitted by local authorities for the appointment of the necessary expertise to monitor and control the disposal of these poisons?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: In principle I would. We are going to have to deal with this problem if we want our industrial development to take off.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Apart from the disposal of toxic waste I am sure the Minister is aware of the danger involved in transporting it. Will the Minister tell the House if there is a licensing system in existence or any system to monitor companies involved in the transport of such waste? Are regulations being prepared to ensure that such waste is transported safely?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I do not have the information available but if the Deputy tables a question I will obtain it for him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: In view of the need for a proper system for the transport and disposal of toxic waste, does the Minister agree that it would be better to establish a national system rather than leave it to different local authorities to introduce their own regulations? There is a need to introduce a uniform method of dealing with this matter. There should be a central system for disposing of the waste, not just dumping it, but burning or recycling it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: That is one of the matters being considered in the overall context of the problem.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Environment Improvement Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the amount of money allocated under the environment improvement scheme to Mallow Urban District Council, County Cork for each year since the inception of the scheme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment the amount of money allocated to the northern committee of Cork County Council under the environmental improvement scheme; and the number of youths employed each year under this scheme since its inception.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - River Corrib Congestion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coogan Mr. Coogan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if he will consider making moneys available to the local authority to enable the congestion at the opening of the River Corrib which has been caused by unprecedented weed growth to be cleared.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Representations to US Government.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the representations he has made or plans to make to the Government of the United States concerning their decision to appoint the US Ambassador to Ireland to spearhead President Reagan's campaign against the peace movement in Western Europe, in view of the possible repercussions for Irish neutrality of this politically sensitive appointment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cooney) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs) Patrick M. Cooney
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Defence (Mr. Cooney) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs)
Speaker.P: It is accepted diplomatic practice for an ambassador to a given country to be temporarily assigned additional special tasks by his Government, which is what I understand to have been done in this case. I would not accept that this matter has any repercussions for Irish foreign policy of the kind implied by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: I find the Minister's reply extraordinary in view of the fact that the United States' Ambassador to Ireland has been appointed as a personal representative to spearhead a propaganda campaign by the American Government to make nuclear weapons more acceptable in Europe. In view of the fact that Ireland is a neutral State will the Minister accept that it is a compromise of our neutrality to allow that ambassador carry out the function I mentioned?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I do not accept that there is any implication of the kind adverted to by the Deputy. It is not unusual for diplomatic representatives to be given other tasks by their countries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Mac Giolla Mr. Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Surely the Minister accepts that, whatever his impression of the matter and how it can be seen, we will be perceived in Europe as at least shilly-shallying on our neutrality when we accept as ambassador to this country a man who is promoting nuclear weapons in Europe? Can the Minister understand the perception of our country and our neutrality which European states will have when they see the US Ambassador to Ireland as President Reagan's and NATOs personal representative in Europe?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: The Deputy is putting to the House his perception of the task given by the US Government to the ambassador here and then assuming that other people will see it in that light. It does not follow.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware of the statement from the American Embassy here that the purpose of the Ambassador's visit to Europe was to try to establish better ways of communications between America and our European partners?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I understand that that is the ambassador's role, a communications role.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: Included in that is an effort to propagate American nuclear policy, with particular reference to the stationing of Cruise missiles in Europe?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I do not know the precise details of the message the ambassador will be given but if his task is a communications one on behalf of his Government obviously he will be endeavouring to explain that to the people he visits.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if it is the intention of the Government to ratify the two United Nations international human rights covenants and optional protocol.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: The question of ratification of these covenants has been under consideration for some time by interested Government Departments. It is envisaged that both covenants will be ratified simultaneously, as has been the general practice followed by other states party to the covenants. Before proceeding to ratification, the Government are anxious to ensure that our domestic legislation enables us to comply fully with the terms of the covenants. In this connction, certain problems remain for us with regard to the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. My Department are actively seeking to resolve these outstanding problems so that we can proceed to early ratification of both covenants. The question of ratifying the optional protocol to the UN Covenant on Civil and Political Rights will be considered when any substantive difficulties in the way of ratification of the covenant itself have been resolved.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: Given that both covenants have been open for ratification since 1966 will the Minister give any indication of the time limit that will be involved in the deliberations the Department are having on the matter? Is the Minister in a position to tell the House within what time span the Government are prepared to ratify those covenants?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: In view of the length of time that the covenants have been open it would be unduly brave of me at this stage to hazard a guess at a time span. However, the Department are actively seeking to resolve these outstanding problems so that we can proceed to early ratification of both covenants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: Does the Minister feel that the matter is more serious now in view of the fact that Ireland has been elected to the UN Commission on Human Rights? We are now in the embarrassing position of calling on other Governments to live up to international standards which we have failed to ratify. Given that that is an extremely embarrassing situation for any country I should like to know if the Minister feels that the matter will be expedited now?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: There is no question of embarrassment in not having ratified the covenants because we are fully in accordance with the European Convention. There is no question of the country lacking in this area generally but, as I indicated to the Deputy, the Department are anxious to proceed to early ratification and the matter is having urgent attention.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: Does the Minister feel that Ireland's credibility in defending human rights internationally has been undermined by our failure to ratify these covenants? The Minister has said he did not feel there was any embarrassment involved but Ireland has been in the position of defending human rights and calling for certain standards in South American and other countries and does he not think our credibility will be undermined by our failure to ratify the covenants mentioned?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: No, I do not.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Integrated Area Proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if a proposal has been sent to the EEC Commission proposing that a joint area embracing the Counties of Donegal, Derry and Tyrone, be designated as an integrated area to receive the maximum involvement by the EEC through their various funds; and, if so, if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: No Irish Government have made a formal proposal to the European Commission that a joint area embracing Counties Donegal, Derry and Tyrone be designated as an integrated area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that a survey was carried out in relation to the social and economic problems prevailing in that area and that it has been established that it is the most impoverished area in western Europe with an unemployment rate of 38 per cent? Does the Minister not consider that his Department and the Government should be making proposals in order to alleviate the chronic unemployment situation which prevails there and extracting from the non-quota section of the regional fund the maximum amount of money in order to deal with the problem?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: This is tied up with the next question. Obviously there have been studies with regard to this area. The Deputy's question was specifically to know if the proposal had been sent to the Commission to designate the area as an integrated area. My information is that no such proposal has been made to the European Commission. Apparently this idea was talked about by the previous Government but nothing happened. Obviously, because of the problems of the area to which the Deputy refers, it is a matter which now requires to be followed up.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: Does the Minister agree that there are at least four areas which we could identify, port development, a duty-free manufacturing industrial zone, a co-ordinated tourist development programme and promotion of reduced energy costs, for this area? These are four areas that would merit attention in relation to being able to do something for the chronic unemployment and the poverty in that area.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I agree with the Deputy that the problems of that area require special attention. If that attention can be given from European sources an approach should be made.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will make a statement on a study carried out by the EEC Commissioner for Social Affairs, Mr. Ivor Richards, on a plan to have an industrial zone straddling the border between Counties Donegal, Derry and Tyrone.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I am not aware of any study carried out by the EEC Commissioner for Social Affairs, Mr. Ivor Richard, on a plan to have an industrial zone straddling the border between Counties Donegal, Derry and Tyrone.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Submarine Monitoring Device.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the representations he has made or plans to make to the United States Government concerning the discovery last March of an electronic device for monitoring submarine activity off the Kerry coast; the measures he has taken to establish from that Government how the device came to be off the Irish coast; the reason the device in question was returned to the US Government; where and on what date it was returned; the payments received from the US Government to compensate Irish taxpayers for the costs involved in removing and transporting the device; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will state, arising from the discovery in March 1982 of an electronic device for monitoring submarine activity off the Kerry coast, whether any more of these devices have been located in Irish waters; whether any of these have been located with the approval of the Irish Government; and if he will make a statement on the possible implications for Irish neutrality of this discovery.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 33 and 34 together.

From inquiries made of the US Embassy here I understand that the object to which the Deputy's question refers was not placed in Irish territorial waters nor on the seabed and that it had broken off a US vessel somewhere at sea. Consequently I have not made representations to the US Government in the sense suggested by the Deputy, nor do I plan to do so.

The object in question was a trailing antenna. This is simply a communications device, much like a car radio antenna, although considerably larger, which is trailed behind vessels, usually submarines, and is used to pick up any acoustic signals in the area.

MainHeading.P: Together with a second such object which had been found at an earlier date, the object in question was returned to the US authorities as a normal courtesy and shipped from Cork on 8 April 1982 by an Irish civilian haulage firm engaged by the US authorities. No reimbursement was sought from the US Government for the very small costs involved in bringing the object found near Dingle to Collins Barracks, Cork.

I am not aware that any objects of the kind mentioned have been found in Irish waters since March 1982. The Government have not received any requests for assistance in locating such objects in Irish waters and have not offered such assistance to other countries. I would not accept that the finding of the object referred to carries any implications for Irish neutrality.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: The Minister stated that the Government were not asked for nor did they offer any assistance. Can the Minister tell the House that there are no such devices off the Irish coast which are used either by the British Government, the American Government or any other Government for the monitoring of shiping off the coast?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: As I indicated in the reply, the apparatus in question was not, as the Deputy thought, an electronic device for monitoring submarine activities. It was a trailing antenna. I have no information about electronic devices.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. De Rossa Mr. De Rossa
Speaker.P: The Minister indicated that the antenna, as he described it, is normally fitted to a submarine. Presumably if it belonged to the American Government it must have been an American submarine that was operating off the Irish coast. Can the Minister indicate for what purpose the American submarine was off the Irish coast?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: Submarines and vessels of all nations regularly pass by the Irish coast and from time to time lose pieces of equipment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: Could the Minister indicate if there is any sharing of information about movements of military shipping off the Irish coast in the Atlantic between America and Britain and ourselves? Do we know exactly what is going on in the area or are we just subject to occasional accidents that have occurred such as those affecting our trawlers, and the suspicion surrounding the Viscount plane crash?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: That is a separate question. All I can say is that if submarines come inside our territorial seas they are required to navigate on the surface.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: Is the Minister satisfied that that is happening in view of the sinking recently of a trawler off the Irish coast and from which the British military authorities admitted responsibility? Is the Minister satisfied that the movement of these ships is on the surface?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: The incident to which the Deputy refers is a separate matter from the question asked and I have no detailed information about it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: It is related to the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: If the Deputy puts down a separate question he will get a reply to it.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Summary Execution Allegation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign affairs if he is concerned by the statements of leaders of the Catholic Church in the North of Ireland and leaders of the Nationalist community there to the effect that members of the British forces and RUC have adopted a new policy of summary execution; and the action he intends to take on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: The Government have noted the statements made by leaders of the Catholic Church in Northern Ireland and by leaders of the Nationalist community there regarding fatal shootings by the security forces. The Government share the widespread concern at these shootings and I made known this concern to the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland when I met him recently in London.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: Could the Minister indicate the response of the Secretary of State in this regard?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: The practice in the past has been that details of discussions at such meetings are kept confidential and the Deputy will appreciate that it would not be proper for me to break with such precedent by revealing these details.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Third World Commitment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if the Government's commitment to achieve the UN target of granting .7 per cent of our GNP by way of aid to the Third World by the end of the 1980's will be met.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will indicate the Government's reasoning behind their decision not to meet the undertaking given by both the Fine Gael and Labour Parties in the course of the last general election on the commitment to increase Third World aid by .05 per cent of GNP each year; and if it is intended to continue to decrease the amount committed by the Government in 1984, 1985 and 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 36 and 37 together.

Ireland's official development assistance in 1983 will amount to £30.076 million. This represents an increase of £5.468 million or more than 22 per cent over the expected outturn of £24.608 million in 1982. The 1983 figure includes £3 million of voted monies in addition to those contained in the Book of Estimates published in November 1982.
ODA in 1983 will amount to .23 per cent of GNP as against .21 per cent in 1982, an increase of .02 per cent.

The Joint Programme for Government of 12 December 1982 states that the Government will adhere to the commitment to increase development aid by .05 per cent of GNP each year until the UN target of 0.7 per cent is reached. However, in the present difficult budgetary situation, it was not possible this year to go beyond the increase to which I have already referred.

MainHeading.P: As ODA in 1983 has, nevertheless, been increased substantially in real terms, the Deputy's reference to an assumed intention on the part of the Government to continue to decrease aid in the years 1984, 1985 and 1986 is not understood.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: It appears the Minister answered the latter part of the question about a decrease in 1984-85. The Coalition have broken a solemn promise given in their joint declaration. Once again they have failed to realise that we as a nation benefit from the Third World as well as contributing towards it——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: A question please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: Is the Minister saying he is not going to meet the commitment given in their joint programme? Is that correct?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: Not this year because of the financial mess we inherited.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: Obviously the same will apply next year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: We will improve things by next year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: Will the Minister give a detailed breakdown under each heading in the Book of Estimates? Is that information available?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I did not hear the Deputy's supplementary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: The Minister probably has the information in his brief. A provision for 1983 would support the figures of £24.5 million and over £30 million in 1982-83, but I have seen no evidence in the Book of Estimates to back up the statement he has just made.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I suggest that the Deputy read the Book of Estimates more carefully or perhaps get somebody more experienced to bring him through it. The figures are in the Book of Estimates.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: The Coalition have once again broken their promise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: In view of the Minister's stated doubts about the use that certain moneys overseas were put to, is he satisfied that these moneys, as allocated, are wisely and properly spent?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cooney Mr. Cooney
Speaker.P: I am well satisfied. I want to make it clear that I am in favour of as much overseas aid as we can give, but because of our limited resources and the size of the problem we have to be careful how this money is spent.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: There are two Private Notice Questions——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: I would like to raise the subject matter of Question No. 281 of 9 February 1983.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair will communicate with the Deputy.
